author: leeastley
title: Danny Higginbotham tries his hand at refereeing… and finds out it is more difficult than it looks
text:
Comments I WAS out running around on a football pitch again this week. 
Apart from it being a slight shock to the system I was surprised to find my positioning was hopeless! Spent time with Chris Foy and Trevor Massey on a referee course for @SkySportsNewsHQ which will be shown next few days. Real eye opener. pic.twitter.com/Kgdp8AJweP 
— Danny Higginbotham (@Higginbotham05) March 22, 2017 
At first, I just couldn’t get in the right areas. I was awful. 
Keep up to date with ALL the latest football news, gossip and rumours 
But, to be fair, I was trying my hand at refereeing — not actually kicking the ball around. 
And, I must say, I have a new-found respect for the men in the middle after my efforts. 
It was a real eye-opener. 
I was with former whistle-blower Chris Foy and his linesman Trevor Massey, who now train referees. 
We were part of a piece for Sky highlighting the great work done by officials up and down the country every weekend. 
Now, I was never one to get in the ref’s face when I was playing. Sky Sports Danny Higginbotham tried his hand at refereeing for a day Sky Sports 5 Danny Higginbotham admitted he found it difficult as a referee 
I wasn’t a huge complainer. I respected referees — but not as much as I respect them now. 
Taking charge of a small-sided college game, the interesting thing was I kept taking up positions as if I was playing — finding space or opening my body up as if to receive a pass. 
But I should have been making sure I could see the bigger picture. 
If a team is attacking, I shouldn’t have been finding myself in the middle of the action. 
I should have been backing up play to get the best view. 
I eventually got the hang of it, and it is all about positioning. It then makes the decision-making so much easier. 
If I do ever want a career as a ref — which I hope is unlikely — I have a couple of other areas to work on. 
In my post-match debrief with Chris, I was told that I kept giving marginal calls against attackers! Weekend Round-Up : Watch the best action from the Premier League Reuters Jamie Vardy was controversially sent off against Stoke 
Apparently, a lot of the play-ons or fouls favoured the men at the back. 
That may not be a surprise given that I was a fully paid-up member of the defenders’ union in my playing days. But, honestly, it was subconscious. 
And the other area of my refereeing that needs cutting out was my running commentary. 
I kept shouting: ‘Great save, keeper’, or ‘good tackle, mate’ or ‘great finish’. 
That’s, of course, the chat you would use as a player — but it doesn’t look good for the ref to be complimenting a player! 
The opposition would soon be saying: ‘What are you on about? Do you support them or something?’ 
Chris told me at half-time to keep a lid on it. Maybe I should keep the whistle in my mouth to stop me talking! 
But when I was playing I always wanted to keep the refs onside, to have some banter with them. And it was good if they could give some back. PA:Press Association 5 Zlatan Ibrahimovic was given a restrosepctive ban for his elbow on Tyrone Mings 
Early in my career I found that easy. I have even traded friendly insults with them in the middle of a match. 
One Premier League ref was quick to point out the size of my ears in one match, which I have mentioned before on these pages. 
I found towards the end of my career that dried up. But I found a level of camaraderie really helped me when I was out in the middle. 
I consciously tried to break the ice, by using first names, having a bit of banter. I think that helps enormously.

'If it happens, it happens' Floyd Mayweather responds to Conor McGregor's claims that he would knock him out 
Anyway, I had eight people watching me referee and I was taking charge of some college kids in a match with nothing riding on it. 
Refereeing a cup final with 80,000 people watching would be a different ball game altogether. 
And that’s why I think we should be a little more hesitant before criticising referees. 
I’m not a fan of more technology — just more understanding. 
If we (viewers, pundits, journalists) need three replays of a decision before deciding if the ref is right or wrong, we should hold off from slamming him. 
Yes, there are some blatant errors that referees need to be called out on, but a lot are subjective, or depend on the angle or what have you. Reuters Sergio Aguero was dismissed against Chelsea after a mass brawl 
Like Jamie Vardy’s sending-off earlier in the season against Stoke. 
I watched it three times from three different angles and reached three different conclusions. 
One of the problems is that there are so many rules — and that so many of them are open to interpretation. 
If you sat ten refs down they would not all come to the same conclusion over one incident. 
That’s why I’m against more technology. 
It’s been brilliant for goalline decisions but leave the game alone. 
And leave the ref alone, too. Especially now that I am one!
